sentence: Since the beginning of 2015, numerous data breaches at high-profile business houses and government agencies prompted the need to impose tighter security measures, which in turn boosted the cyber security stocks.
On Jun 5, these stocks gained further momentum on news that nearly every government agency's personnel data has been hacked.
The latest data breach was reported late the previous day by the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), a U.S. federal agency that keeps employee information and handles security clearances.
Per the agency, nearly 4 million current and former federal U.S. employees' personal data has been compromised.
The latest breach at the OPM has proved the government's data protection measures inadequate, especially in the wake of increasingly sophisticated attacks.
This follows a couple of high-profile data breaches at Target Corp. TGT and The Home Depot Inc. HD , wherein customer data was compromised.
But believe it or not, there does appear to be a positive side to this episode.
A data breach is good news for cyber security companies, because it increases the chances of security-related purchases by both companies and governments.
So investors flock to the shares sending up share prices.
This time was no different: CyberArk Software Ltd. CYBR and FireEye Inc. FEYE were the top gainers witnessing 7.4% and 6.4% rise, respectively.
This was followed by Fortinet Inc. FTNT and Palo Alto Networks Inc. PANW gaining a respective of 3.9% and 2.9%.
Year-to-date, CyberArk gained the most - 67% - followed by FireEye, Palo Alto and Fortinet with approximately 62%, 42% and 34% share price rise, respectively.
What is Driving This Growth?
The demand for cyber security is on the rise.
Over the past few quarters, cyber security providers have witnessed double-digit top-line growth, which according to the companies was primarily due to the increasing number of large deal signings.

It should also be noted that cyber security companies are witnessing double-digit growth, while the overall IT spending is anticipated to grow just under 3% in 2015, according to the research firm Gartner.

The recent deal between FireEye and Visa Inc. V to develop joint threat intelligence tools and services for card issuing companies is an example of how much financial service providing companies are committed to avoid data breaches.

Furthermore, last month, global telecom service provider, Vodafone, implemented CyberArk's selected solutions - CyberArk Enterprise Password Vault and CyberArk Privileged Session Manager - to provide data security to its privileged accounts.
With rapid technological advancement, more organizations are adopting the "bring your own device" (BYOD) policy to enhance employee productivity with anytime, anywhere access.
This trend, on the other hand, has made it necessary for companies to enforce stricter data security measures.
Moreover, the incidents at Anthem Inc. ANTM and Sony Corp. SNE earlier this year boosted the need for cyber security products.
Also, we expect the increasing spending on IT security to benefit cyber security companies, going forward.
Per Gartner, worldwide spending on IT security in 2014 was about $70 billion which is likely to reach $76.9 billion in 2015.

Some Hot Picks in the Cyber Security Space

We expect the aforementioned factors to drive continued growth at cyber security companies.
Therefore, it makes sense to invest in this hot industry group.
Here are some top-ranked stocks that should be rewarding over the long term.
VASCO, sporting a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), has a long-term EPS growth rate of 15%.
This is much higher than the industry average of 10%.
The company has also surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in each of the last four quarters with an average positive surprise of 158.06%.
The company is expected to report its second-quarter 2015 earnings results on Jul 23.
This Zacks Rank #2 (Buy) IT security provider has a long-term EPS growth rate of 25%, much higher than the industry average of 14.3%.
The company has not yet completed a year of public trading, but has performed extremely well in this short time span.
Third quarter 2014 results under U.S. SEC regulations were reported publicly for the first time and its earnings beat our consensus estimate by a whopping 1600%.
CyberArk has gained momentum since then, surpassing the Zacks Consensus for fourth-quarter 2014 earnings by 1800% and first-quarter 2015 by 275%.
Indeed, CyberArk's growth rate is too significant to ignore.
The company is expected to post its next earnings results on Aug 7.
AVG currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 and trades at a forward P/E of 15.6x, much lower than the industry average of 32.9x.
Also, the company has surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the last four quarters with an average positive surprise of 14.07%.
The company is expected to report its second-quarter 2015 earnings results on Jul 29.
